title: Finding Community in the Season
devotional:
Old Man Hemlock sat on the park bench, watching the town square bustle with pre-holiday activity. Christmas lights twinkled, casting a warm glow on the faces of shoppers hurrying by with bags full of gifts. He felt a pang of loneliness. His family was scattered across the country, and he hadn’t heard from them much lately. He missed the days when his house was filled with the sounds of laughter, wrapping paper crinkling, and the aroma of freshly baked cookies. 

Suddenly, a young boy, no older than seven, approached Hemlock. The boy’s eyes were wide with wonder as he gazed at the Christmas tree towering in the center of the square. “It’s so big!” he exclaimed. “And sparkly!” Hemlock smiled. “It is, isn’t it? What’s your name, son?”

“I’m Leo,” the boy replied. “My mom is getting hot chocolate. She said I could look at the tree, but I can’t leave this spot.” Hemlock chuckled. “Well, Leo, it’s a pleasure to meet you. I’m Hemlock.”

They sat in comfortable silence for a few moments, both captivated by the Christmas tree. Then, Leo turned to Hemlock and asked, “Are you waiting for someone?”

“I suppose I am,” Hemlock said, his voice tinged with melancholy. “I’m waiting for that feeling of community, you know? The one that seems to appear every December, then vanishes on December 26th.”

Leo tilted his head, considering this. “My grandma says community is like… like a big blanket,” he said hesitantly. “It keeps you warm when you’re cold and covers you when you’re scared. But you have to share it, or it won’t work right.”

Hemlock stared at the young boy, surprised by his wisdom. “A big blanket, huh?” he mused. “I like that.” Leo’s mother returned with two cups of hot chocolate. She smiled at Hemlock. “Thank you for keeping him company,” she said. “Merry Christmas!”

As they walked away, Hemlock watched them go, realizing Leo was right. Community isn't something that magically appears; it's something we create, something we share. It isn't limited to familial or holiday events. It's an active effort to connect with those around us, offering warmth, support, and a sense of belonging. Maybe that lonely bench was an opportunity to connect after all.
image_description: A snow-covered park bench facing a large, brightly lit Christmas tree in a town square.
insights: Leo’s simple explanation of community as a “big blanket” resonates with the biblical understanding of fellowship. Hebrews 10:24-25 encourages us to “spur one another on toward love and good deeds… encouraging one another.” This highlights the active role we play in building community. It's not a passive experience but an intentional act of offering support, encouragement, and love to those around us. The passage emphasizes the importance of gathering together and investing in each other. Likewise, Paul often reminds the churches he is writing to that they are a body, and each part is as important as the others. Community comes about when everyone embraces this notion.
prayer: Heavenly Father, forgive me for the times I've isolated myself and longed for connection without actively seeking it. Open my eyes to the opportunities around me to build community, to offer warmth and support to those who need it. Help me to be a part of the “big blanket” that comforts and connects us all. Show me how to love and serve those around me, and enable me to see my purpose with them. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: How can you actively participate in building community this week? Is there someone you could reach out to, offer support to, or simply connect with? Consider those who may be feeling lonely or isolated. Community comes when we actively seek it.
